[h3]Could it be better? Sure... But picture this:[/h3]

You start the game, you know nothing about it, only that it's a survival game. It opens up and you're in an escape pod. You're falling to the ground fast! You rush for the controls to see if you can actually control it in any way... You can, but only left and right. Maybe I should aim for the water? Crash! My eyes open and I'm on the ground, outside the escape pod and apparently hurt. A little text shows up and tells me to check the escape pod for anything useful. There are some bandages, rations and other titbits. The text shows up again and it turns out I have a little AI companion that helps me out, it suggests I look for food. Soon I find some and the AI tells me about my survival suit can make a mini constructor for processing things. OK, cool, wait... What are those creatures over there, are they dangerous? Ah no, it appears to be some sort of cow. So I install my constructor and discover I can make a tent and a tool for harvesting/mining. Suddenly out of nowhere something bites me! I run as I look back they appear to be some sort of spiders. I reach the edge of the water and I jump without thinking! It turns out I can swim and hold my breath for a bit. 

I notice something at the bottom of the lake/river. My AI tells me I can make fuel out of it, cool! Ouch! Something bites me again I swim to the surface and head for the opposite coast... When I reach it I see these weird looking sea creatures follow me out, but they don't stray far from the water. At this point the sun is going down and I'm getting cold. I look through the things I can build and it turns out there's a heater, but I need a rock to extract metal from. OK, I find one, craft it and put it to work, but it only works in close proximity. Suddenly, what appears to be a small dinosaur appears out of nowhere and starts attacking me... I barely have time to escape with my things. I jump in the water again and swim to what appears to be a small island. 

I decide that making a cave is probably the safest thing. I set my tent, my constructor and my heater down. I have a bite to eat but I get sick! I must've eaten something bad. My AI tells me I can take a specific medicine to cure myself, but for that I need some leaves. I venture out into the mini forest on the island and I find them. I craft them and I'm cured. I hear a sound of relief! I head back to my cave and the sun has set on the horizon. The colours are beautiful and they reflect on the water. I can also hear insects and animals far away. I take a moment to enjoy and take it all in and suddenly I hear an ungodly scream right behind me. I turn, but it's pitch black.. Suddenly the ugliest face of the ugliest creature I've ever seen appears from the shadows, boom! I'm dead. My heart is racing, I look at the time, it's only been 20 minutes and I can respawn nearby. I think I'll just start again, that's was intense!

Empyrion is an enjoyable game that offers a range of play styles, from quick and easy to hard and challenging, both solo and co-op. Compared to other space-based games, Empyrion stands out for its engaging mining and crafting mechanics.

In contrast, Space Engineers has impressive graphics but for me it soon becomes monotonous due to the lack of interesting gameplay elements and the feeling of grinding for ages to get anywhere. Much of the interesting game content has been made into DLCs, making it feel like a bigger disapointment as you get into it, without spending extra money. Additionally, the game's quite empty space (a few pirates and spiders, but not much else), empty planets and lack of addition of meaningful NPCs made exploration feel lonely. Ships are fragile and crashes a pain in the neck. It's got a few dials, but crash physics are pretty much on or off, and not much in between, 

Then there's No Man's Sky which I still enjoy, they have good success with NPC interactions but can feel repetitive after a while. The ships and buildings are modular and largely prefab, unlike the block level in SE or Empyrion, but do at least make slightly less painful building experiences, the game's pace also doesn't allow for easy pausing or saving as compared to  Empyrion which addresses these issues by offering more flexible gameplay options and allowing players to pause and save at their convenience.

I acknowledges that no game is perfect but I still enjoy playing Empyrion after 5000+ hours, it's engaging gameplay mechanics, adjustable difficulty settings, and freedom to play as desired make it one of my all time favourites.

So in summary, IMO it's really good value.  The graphics are pretty good, no not perfect camera quality, the physics are also pretty good, and crashes not so punishing, and the gameplay is pretty good. If you want fun without too much of a grind you can.

This review of the game is based around the mod Reforged Eden 2, it's a rework mod that updates all the standard systems and makes the game playable. Very few people play without it, all the positives mentioned in my review will be directly coming from RE2 and not from the vanilla game. 

----------------------

Pros:

- RE2 introduces a really nice complex ship building system. Tons of dynamic depth and you can spend tens of hours in the build menu learning about it and working out how it works. It's overwhelming at first but is a genuinely interesting experience and is a step-up from vanilla, please keep in mind that vanilla is very simple by comparison when buying the game.

- Dungeons (points of interest) are a mixture of small puzzles and pve zones. You clear enemies, work through the puzzle, then disable the core of the base so you can properly salvage modules and materials from it. Great experience with these so far, my only complaint is enemies spawn-in a bit jarringly near you, and the core of the base could do with better dynamic AI so that they patrol levels properly. Vanilla AI is dead and does absolutely nothing so you need the mod to do much with these.

- The suit system in vanilla is just a 3 stage upgrade system that has you move from light through to heavy armour for better upgrades. In RE2 light, medium, and heavy armour instead has a complex system of sidegrades. Light armour offers more movement and flexibility, medium armour offers good protection with some minor movement limitations, and heavy armour offers optimal protection at the cost of decreased movement and increased food/resource upkeep. There are a number of specialist sub-grades for light and heavy armour as well which offer specialised upgrades/debuffs.

- Base building in this game is a really fun experience. Ground bases are pretty good but it really takes off when you make a space station and have to manage the importing of goods from autominer/oxygen outposts to the base. On your own it's a bit of a slog but with a group of friends you can assign people to do different things and managing the base becomes enjoyable.

Cons:

- Character animations, in both first person and third person, are quite poor. They need to be drastically reworked to be up to modern standards. The vast majority are pretty much just standard asset unity store purchased animations and a lot of the reload animations don't make sense for the gun you're using. Your character also stands in a very weird squat when using the jetpack and there's no animation transitions so you instantly snap between your idle animation and the weapon usage animation.

- Alien models are incredibly poor quality and they need to be updated. They're much lower quality than the player model quality, which itself has issues, and they move and look as though they're ripped from a Playstation 2 game.

- Gun animations in first and third person are pretty bad as well. The pistol in third person is held a solid foot above the players head for some reason, the miningun in third person makes you spread your legs and squat when walking around, and generally there are similar issues for everything in-game.

- There isn't enough armour variety visually both in vanilla and Re2. There are 3 models used and that's it forever. Titan armour/epic armour should have a unique heavy armour model variant just for it. Federation/polaris armour, and improved/advanced variants, should all have unique models as well. As it stands you don't feel any true progression visually because of it.

- The building menu is incredibly janky and needs many quality-of-life upgrades. It's an incredibly painful system to use for big builds and it doesn't save block choices, rotation settings, or selections for a lot of things.

I really want to like this game.  There's no other game that really fits this scifi niche the way Empyrion does.

I was excited when I saw there was a 10th anniversary release.  I literally bought this game 10 years ago next month, and I have 101 hours.  I've played it off and on over the years, and early on I thought it had a lot of potential.  And Empyrion does _a lot_.  But it does it all a little poorly.

The whole game just lacks polish, which is what you would expect devs to be doing over maybe the last 3-5 years of a 10-year development span.  It's not like they quit working on it, they just keep adding new content while neglecting the base game mechanisms.  The quality-of-life things I expected to be developed in 10 years just aren't there... and as the game got more complicated (inventory logistics, etc) the game got harder to understand and play.  It really takes some serious investment to explore everything this game has to offer, which can be a good thing if mastering a difficult system is what you're after.

Examples of friction: 

A block-based base builder, still doesn't have a "eye-dropper" texture picker to match a placed block's texture with the texture tool.

The tutorial system is very extensive, but also difficult to understand and broken in places.

Enemy AI that is at the level of a college intro course to Game AI Programming.

Item descriptions and stat blocks that are inconsistent... the basic base defense autocannon doesn't say what ammo it requires in the constructor description, but other base weapons do.  You have access to base and vehicle building blocks at the beginning of the game, and it's not obvious that, as just one example, the Large window is for bases and space ships, and the Small window is for personal vehicles.  Or that the constructor doesn't draw from your personal inventory, so when you construct a hoverbike with a "Hoverbike Construction Kit" in your inventory, it automatically builds a _new_ kit to build the Hoverbike.

It's totally not intuitive that the "blueprint factory" happens in your pocket, when basic building blocks can't even be built in the portable constructor.  The tutorial explains it, but it's confusing because it's totally not how you expect it to work.

Every time you run out of building block and fetch a new pile from storage, it forgets what wall type you were placing and reverts to the default block.  And you can't just middle-click on a block and "pick" that type/texture.  You have to right-click and find it in the menu again... and there are a ton of options.  Good for options, bad for being such a cumbersome building system.

It's not that none of these things don't _work_, it's just such a struggle to learn and then interact with the systems, because they're not intuitive, not always well designed (non-intuitive menus, poor feedback about why something doesn't work the way you expect, for something as simple as picking up a base defense gun from storage doesn't say your inventory is over-loaded, it tells you to put it in your inventory bar to place it.)

If you really like this kind of game, sci-fi planet-side base-building survival that scales into space-ship building, leaving the planet, and then building more bases on more hostile planets, then what the game _does_ do may outweigh its flaws for you.  It did for me for 100 hours.  But I gave up after 4 this time... this game is just too frustrating and time-consuming for the enjoyment it gives at this point, when I've got so many other, newer, more polished games in my queue.

I figure, if you haven't discovered Empyrion by now, it's probably not for you.

I really want to like this game.  There's no other game that really fits this scifi niche the way Empyrion does.

I was excited when I saw there was a 10th anniversary release.  I literally bought this game 10 years ago next month, and I have 101 hours.  I've played it off and on over the years, and early on I thought it had a lot of potential.  And Empyrion does _a lot_.  But it does it all a little poorly.

The whole game just lacks polish, which is what you would expect devs to be doing over maybe the last 3-5 years of a 10-year development span.  It's not like they quit working on it, they just keep adding new content while neglecting the base game mechanisms.  The quality-of-life things I expected to be developed in 10 years just aren't there... and as the game got more complicated (inventory logistics, etc) the game got harder to understand and play.  It really takes some serious investment to explore everything this game has to offer, which can be a good thing if mastering a difficult system is what you're after.

Examples of friction: 

A block-based base builder, still doesn't have a "eye-dropper" texture picker to match a placed block's texture with the texture tool.

The tutorial system is very extensive, but also difficult to understand and broken in places.

Enemy AI that is at the level of a college intro course to Game AI Programming.

Item descriptions and stat blocks that are inconsistent... the basic base defense autocannon doesn't say what ammo it requires in the constructor description, but other base weapons do.  You have access to base and vehicle building blocks at the beginning of the game, and it's not obvious that, as just one example, the Large window is for bases and space ships, and the Small window is for personal vehicles.  Or that the constructor doesn't draw from your personal inventory, so when you construct a hoverbike with a "Hoverbike Construction Kit" in your inventory, it automatically builds a _new_ kit to build the Hoverbike.

It's totally not intuitive that the "blueprint factory" happens in your pocket, when basic building blocks can't even be built in the portable constructor.  The tutorial explains it, but it's confusing because it's totally not how you expect it to work.

Every time you run out of building block and fetch a new pile from storage, it forgets what wall type you were placing and reverts to the default block.  And you can't just middle-click on a block and "pick" that type/texture.  You have to right-click and find it in the menu again... and there are a ton of options.  Good for options, bad for being such a cumbersome building system.

It's not that none of these things don't _work_, it's just such a struggle to learn and then interact with the systems, because they're not intuitive, not always well designed (non-intuitive menus, poor feedback about why something doesn't work the way you expect, for something as simple as picking up a base defense gun from storage doesn't say your inventory is over-loaded, it tells you to put it in your inventory bar to place it.)

If you really like this kind of game, sci-fi planet-side base-building survival that scales into space-ship building, leaving the planet, and then building more bases on more hostile planets, then what the game _does_ do may outweigh its flaws for you.  It did for me for 100 hours.  But I gave up after 4 this time... this game is just too frustrating and time-consuming for the enjoyment it gives at this point, when I've got so many other, newer, more polished games in my queue.

I figure, if you haven't discovered Empyrion by now, it's probably not for you.
